comments.commentBody: Attacking a judge is one thing, but attacking the judge who is hearing your own case is very different.  If Trump's judge is really biased against Trump, he is required to recuse himself and faces penalties if he doesnt.  Trump should produce some evidence beyond adverse rulings or find himself in contempt of court.

If a lawyer behaved that way toward the judiciary, he would be sanctioned or perhaps even disbarred; if a member of congress behaved that way toward a sitting judge, they would risk formal censure; if a child behaved that way, he/she would be grounded with no internet for a month. Alas, the GOP and the press hold Trump to a much lower standard.

Who created Donald Trump- the Presidential Candidate? "We did":

Collectively, *we* sat by tacitly will our Congressional representatives on the right[sic] side of the aisle did all they could to bring the entire U.S. Government to a screeching halt ( and the left side wrung their collective hands) because the *Black Man* in the White House was too uppity.

*We* collectively created Donald Trump when each voter continued to select representatives that denigrated fellow citizens as worthless leeches and we gladly agreed. *We* collectively created Donald Trump when we gladly listed to, and talked back to our radios and televisions with loud Whoops when Glen Beck, Sean Hannity, Rush and the rest made ludicrous statements about the President and indulged in fantastical conspiracy theories.
*We* collectively created Donald Trump when ever we dehumanized a person of color- be it a skinny girl in a bathing suit being body slammed into the sidewalk; another child of color being flipped out of a school chair; another dead body of color without nary a query. *We* collective created Donald Trump when every social malaise, we chalked up to personal human failure- never realizing; " There but by the grace of God"..

*We* collectively created Donald Trump by simply and profoundly treating each other like crap and now wonder why he proudly does the same.

The real risk is that his comments will become normalized if the press doesn't start doing the job they should have been doing all along - holding his feet to the fire every time he makes an outrageous comment. The press conference today is a good foreshadowing of what the press can expect if they dare to criticize the Donald but if they hold back, shame on them. Considering that the real incoming fire is yet to come, I wonder if he can make it through without completely blowing up. We should all pray that will happen before this terrible man somehow gets elected.

The leaders of every major nation are watching and evaluating every word; gesture; nod of the head by The Donald. They are coming to the conclusion, if not already that Trump is no way under any circumstances capable of being the President of the United States.  Putin of Russia and the wing nut from North Korea must be laughing watching the evening news and licking their chops at the first chance to take on this boob.

You are hitting a straw man. The issue isn't if a judge should be sacrosanct but the specifics of Trump's response. It would be one thing if Trump had offered a reasoned critique of the merits of Judge Curiel's rulings in the case or had offered a substantive reason why he should recuse himself or why Curiel was unqualified. Trump offered nothing like any of that.

Instead, he engaged in a vituperative personal attack that first involved racist stereotyping in that he, by applying the word "Mexican", alluded that Curiel was somehow not truly American and that, because Curiel is of Mexican descent, somehow out to get Trump. This isn't a reasoned anything but is simply the substanceless and arguably racist bluster of a paranoid narcissist. Likewise, smears like ""they ought to look into Judge Curiel because what Judge Curiel is doing is a total disgrace" isn't anything except a case of childish bullying, especially since Curiel cannot, in fact, respond in kind.

Critiques of judges by the NYTimes (and I'll assume yours), speak to either the merits of the ruling or have something substantive to say about the qualifications of the judge. Attempting to compare those to Trump's diatribe is like comparing an apple to an orangutan.

Trump's insults to the judge show just how scared this little boy is. When cornered or challenged he attacks. Trump U was as phony as he is.

HUUGGE numbers of Americans are very tired of his nonsense and the numbers will grow. I loved his lash out at the press today when confronted with the "fake to the wallet" he did regarding donations to veteran's groups.
Hey, little boy, to paraphrase a popular saying, "donate like no one is watching!"

Last thing.
President Nixon thought he could be above law and public scrutiny when he instructed his attorney general to fire the independent investigator his justice department tasked with investigating Watergate related charges. The attorney general of the US, AND the second in charge resigned on a Saturday night rather than carry out Nixon's commands. Amazing.
The Saturday Night Massacre I was called at the time.

The following week Americans turned on the president who thought he was above law and public opinion.
People called him a Czar and that was the beginning of the end for Nixon.

Trump is too stupid and full of himself to excerise caution or decorum.

A public buzz saw awaits little boy.
No one is above it all.
No one.
And only he doesn't know that.

How many times have I thought "Donald Trump has hit a new low?" The crazy thing is he never reaches a bottom.

I'm a lawyer and judges have ruled against my position. That's what happens, they call balls and strikes. Adverse rulings don't mean the judge is a "hater." Sometimes they just mean that the judge thinks you are wrong. And the gratuitous mention of Trump's "belief" that the judge is Mexican is beyond disgusting.

I spent most of my professional career in the courtroom, from paralegal to consultant on appellant matters.

While I have worked on teams that represented clients who would rant and rave against the unfairness of the trier of fact - judge or jury - that was hearing their case, it was always considered beyond the pale to make such statements publicly let alone to the press.

To impugn the race of the sitting judge from the dais of a stage on which that client was in his or her role as a seeker of as position as a public servant - the public servant - would have been unimaginable to even the most crass and bellicose of our clients - and we would have withdrawn from representation immediately.

Trump has no concept of or respect for the social morays that hold us together as a civilized society, in fact he he delights in acting as though he - of all of us - is above them - and that we call him on it at our own peril.

He has even gone so far as to incite to violence with impunity.

He reminds me of those who would stand on the saloon porch and rile the mob into teeth gnashing, mind numbing anger, not to be assuaged without a lynching and then say "I never touched the guy. It was them, they done it."

Only he is not standing on a saloon porch but an international stage, and it is not a riled up mob but the American electorate and he is not some local troublemaker but candidate for the leader of the most powerful country on earth and the "lynching"? We can only imagine.

The ugliness of the presidential campaign proper will know no bounds, a dirty dig below the waist to 340 years of nation building.

Win or lose however, the damage is done; the losses on the books. That other universe of brainwashed anger-sinks, who drink in the refreshment of non stop poison, is now immune to the poison. That which would kill any other political career only makes Trump's stronger.

Until this grotesque sore loser takes leave of the public stage - and this likely not before he shuffles off this mortal coil - every rebuke, whether judicial or electoral, will be met by fantastical pot shots, the next more bizarre and virulent and inciting than the last. And the millions of beyond-delusional disciples will react in proportional measure. Eventually ...

The poor thinker Donald Trump, slowed only by prior turns through Chapter 11, thinks nothing of the mother of all bankruptcies: the massive moral one. With the 2008 financial meltdown as a guide, Trump reckons that being a billionaire makes him immune from the consequences of his actions. And tough luck if 330 million others won't have that same luxury.

To quote from a winsome old dirge, "Ain't it funny how one insect can damage so much grain."

Amazing that this buffoon is still a candidate for president, but as PT Barnum said more or less, "No one went broke underestimating the intelligence of the American public."  And, of course, Donald "loves the uneducated."  Just hope they wake up & realize he doesn't care about them at all, just his ego.

1. the people who support Trump don't care. In fact, the more outrageous he acts, the more they love him. They think he's speaking truth to power, not acting like a petulant child.

2. The people who loathe him just have further reason to do so.

3. Those in the middle, who feel it's their civic duty to vote, but can't bring themselves to vote for Hillary, will hold their noses and vote for him anyway and hope for the best.

This is pretty simple. He's losing the law suit. Trump U.'s modus operandi will be outed as a cold blooded scam. So Trump lashes out without the slightest bit of self control. If you can call John McCain a loser for being captured and spending years in a hole in the ground, castigating a federal judge is small potatoes.

Plenty of people are more than alarmed ... but there are many who love him for exactly the reasons you cite ... he's intemperate, and so are they. He's angry, and so are they. He's a reflection of the people who are voting for him. Ignorant, intemperate, ill-informed, poorly-educated ... the electorate the GOP has been busy crafting for the past decades ... and now the GOP establishment is embracing Trump because they think he'll deliver the White House to them. Do they care about the people who will elect him? These are the same people they've been ignoring for decades.

There is a silver lining: Hillary will be elected President. And The Fool we know as Donald J. Trump will be forever known to the entire world as the malicious and unhinged menace that he always has been (in need of treatment for his obviously untreated mental illnesses).

The Times reported that Trump has gotten $2 billion of free media attention. It will turn out to be a blessing: the net result will be the total demolition of Donald J. Trump, by his own out-of-control words and actions. I feel sorry for he and his family. The end will be neither pretty, nor will it occur quietly.

With respect Richard are you serious? Donald Trump he isn't "criticizing" the judge he is launching a full-scale racist attack. There is a difference.

Here is an example: I disagree with Judge So & So. Her interpretation of the law in Case X is in my opinion a misinterpretation of thus and such.

We criticize judges, Supreme Court justices even, all the time. We say, the Chief Justice is wrong, or the liberal justices are wrong - they are too activist, they are too ideological, etc.

What we do not do is launch full scale racist attacks on judges and accuses them of conspiring with President Obama to bring down Donald Trump because of being Mexican and a "hater."

My goodness do you honestly not see the problem here?

This person is running for president of the US. Imagine him with the power to order Mexican judges to prison. Maybe he shuts down the newspaper altogether or journalists mysteriously drop dead.

This is what happens in dictatorships. We have our form of government because the powers of justice, the executive, the legislative offset each other, balance each other, and because the free press, protected by the First Amendment, is able to openly criticize any or all of the above, challenge the pronouncements and behavior of the mighty without fear of repercussion.

That goes for any one of us. We can stand in the public square and criticize Citizen Trump.

I'm not sure if we could freely criticize President Trump though.

Are you?

"You don't sell products, benefits, or solutions - you sell feelings."

Fact: That's from the sales playbook for Trump 'University'.

As everyone can see, the same con underlies his political campaign as well, for he would rather blow his dog whistle of a campaign slogan "Make America Great AGAIN", than detail any sensible policy solutions to the country's issues.

But, he's not just a con man. He's dangerous. Trump is willing to embrace any extremist in his lust for power. He has time to tweet against a female reporter first thing in the morning, but he can't condemn the anti-Semitic tweets harassing a reporter doing his job? He can't remember or denounce David Duke when asked? Trump is willing to bring down anyone, any group, any institution that comes in his way. He will attack the media should he get a question he doesn't like. He will attack the judge hearing a legitimate case against him (Trump couldn't even legally call that con a "university"). He's already talked about giving illegal orders to the armed forces (torture). That's what a Trump presidency would look like.

Donald Trump is dangerous, and must be stopped.

Hmm...yes that very perusal finds the following illustrations of the two men being on opposite sides of the fitness for Presidency in temperament question:
Trump calls the judge "very hostile” and a “hater of Donald Trump,” and said he “should be ashamed of himself. I think it’s a disgrace that he’s doing this.”

...Obama's comments of the ruling against him: Mr. Obama vowed (Tuesday) to appeal the court ruling and expressed confidence that he would prevail in the legal battle to defend his signature domestic policy achievement. “The law is on our side, and history is on our side,” he declared.

...aside from the obvious difference in tenor...what comparisons can you draw except that in the Obama case the judges are conservatives: Judge Hanen had been an "unusually expressive critic of the Obama administration’s immigration policies. In his decision to impose the injunction, he said the president’s initiatives amounted to an abdication of immigration enforcement. The two appeals judges who upheld the injunction are also conservatives."

What Judge Curiel did was provide the access to information under the FOIA, an indisputable and non partisan act in civil cases.

I went back to read precisely what Obama said about Citizens United and Supreme Court in his State of the Union address:

"With all due deference to separation of powers, last week the Supreme Court reversed a century of law that I believe will open the floodgates for special interests –- including foreign corporations –- to spend without limit in our elections. I don't think American elections should be bankrolled by America's most powerful interests, or worse, by foreign entities. They should be decided by the American people. And I'd urge Democrats and Republicans to pass a bill that helps to correct some of these problems."

Fair readers can judge those remarks for themselves.

Did he insult the members of the Supreme Court, as you claim? If so, where?

Did he say they were biased or corrupt? If so, where?

Rather, he argued that they had overturned precedent; stated what he viewed as the likely outcome; and requested a legislative remedy (just as conservatives so often have, e.g., Kelo, RFRA).

We can debate whether it was appropriate to make these remarks with the justices in the room, rather than waiting for them to leave. However, please explain why they are morally equivalent to an individual insulting the judge sitting on his own civil case, and offering no evidence to support his claims of judicial bias other than the judge's ancestry.

Kindly be specific; as you know as an attorney, calling the rest of us ignorant is not an argument.

No. That article proves precisely the opposite.

The Obama administration has filed legal briefs making counterarguments; neither Obama nor his legal advisors have made it personal or claimed the judge is corrupt. They may feel that way in private, but they show full respect for the process.

In contrast, Trump stands in front of a crowd, offering no evidence -- legal or otherwise -- and declares that his judge, who has had an exceptionally honorable and courageous career serving governments of both parties -- is dishonest, and darkly notes that he "is Mexican."

When a judge enjoins an Obama program, Obama complies. Do you honestly think President Trump will accept the same limits on his authority?

There are two ways to disagree: one within the rule of law, and another, Trump's, by showing contempt of it. Conservatives once understood -- or claimed to understand -- the difference.

Trump is a towering mass of pulsating ego. Nothing that happens in his world is impersonal. Like a toddler, Trump believes and behaves as if every action of every other human is centered on him.

We have an emotional three year old running for the most powerful office in the nation, and maybe the world. Trump's reaction t the judge in the Trump University lawsuit, is the equivalent of a toddler having a breakdown tantrum in the supermarket because Mommy didn't buy the blue applesauce or candy. Can't we just give him a time out, have him sit on the Calm Down Chair until November passes?

Unfortunately, what Trump demonstrates is that we have a lot more three year olds voting, and at least some voters who are like the parents you see in public, giving into the whining and tantrums so that they can have some peace.

Sadly, we are about to elect a schoolyard bully. His only weapons are taunts and insults that are fit for a child. And the Right call this presidential. Imagine if elected, will he insult foreign leaders whom don't share his worldview on different policy issues. Say what you want about Obama, at least he never conducted himself that way with the media or when he twice campaigned for president. I guess that Hope and Change wasn't so bad after all. Compared to Trump might as well put President Obama on Mount Rushmore.

Unfortunately Trump is the republican candidate for president, I cannot see how that will change.  The party, for the most part, has accepted it and seems willing to accept him.  For us democrats, it has been kind of funny and unbelievable, but in the back of our minds we know there is always a chance he will win and that is very scary.  We need the media to start doing its job.  The money Trump raised for the military so he wouldnt have to do the last debate, that would have never materialized if not for the press questioning who got the money; even then Trump put them on the defensive.  I hope that when Hillary and Donald have their debates, they are real policy debates, not just name calling by Trump; but I doubt it as everybody in the media seems to let him run the show.

More scary stuff.  Does anyone know how many times The Donald has sued or threatened to sue because he didn't like what someone said about him or thought he was the victim of an injustice?  The Donald is a sociopath with no moral compass that I can see.  He obviously fails to see the danger of his off the chart rhetoric and the poor example he sets.  It boggles my mind that people find him in any way appealing or qualified to be president.  I imagine him as nothing less than a banana republic dictator.  He talks and acts like one.  What will he do to the press when he doesn't like their questions or the things they report?  What will he do to his political "enemies"?  He clearly has no respect for women.  How do people not see this?  It's grotesque and frightening to think he could actually win.  Shame on Republicans who have been highly critical, yet now say they will support him.  Party power clearly means more to them than the welfare of this country.  They apparently believe they can control a loose cannon.

The power of Trump’s campaign comes from allowing Americans to hate. I’m surprised so many of my fellow citizens are like that, but there it is. Muslims, Hispanics, women, LGBTs, blacks, the news media, the handicapped, the Japanese, environmentalists, NATO and now, “Mexican” judges — whoever you want to blame for your troubles or shortcomings, go ahead, and let me set the example. I think support for “Make America Hate Again” is a sign of inner weakness, perhaps helplessness, and, to compensate, a need to be part of a gang led by an authority figure, to feel something resembling strength.

Fortunately, I believe those are in a minority. Most of us wake up, work hard, try to do the right thing, deal with life’s struggles, be good to the people around us, and maintain an individual moral code of decency and fairness. It’s not always easy (I know that I often fall short) but we hold on to the hope and promise of creating something better -- and that, I think, creates the greatness of our country.
